docs.abstract: We invite service members and veterans to weigh in how they have been invoked in reactions to Nike’s new campaign and the community response to N.F.L. players kneeling during the national anthem.
docs.snippet: We invite service members and veterans to weigh in how they have been invoked in reactions to Nike’s new campaign and the community response to N.F.L. players kneeling during the national anthem.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Monday, Nike debuted a new advertisement featuring Colin Kaepernick, the former N.F.L. player whose public protest against police violence during the national anthem prompted leaguewide demonstrations from players that continue today. The ad, which was first released via tweet by Kaepernick days before the start of the N.F.L. season, brought strong reactions on social media, with supporters sharing the #JustDoIt hashtag and those opposed to it using the hashtag #NikeBoycott and sharing videos and photos of them removing the Nike logo from their clothing.

headline.main: How Do You Feel About the N.F.L. Players’ Protests?

docs.abstract: We’re asking readers to tell us about their family members who served during World War I.
docs.snippet: We’re asking readers to tell us about their family members who served during World War I.
docs.lead_paragraph: Nov. 11 will mark 100 years since World War I ended. More than four million Americans served in the armed forces during the war, and millions more people from other countries fought on battlefields across Europe even before the United States entered the conflict.

headline.main: We Want to Hear Your Family’s Stories From World War I

docs.abstract: For this issue, a septuagenarian who still throws himself at the natural world.
docs.snippet: For this issue, a septuagenarian who still throws himself at the natural world.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: “There was no question in our minds that we would use a portrait of Aleksander Doba, the 71-year-old Polish man who has kayaked across the Atlantic Ocean three times, for the cover of this Voyages issue. I mean, look at him! He already seems to be plotting his next journey.”

headline.main: Behind the Cover: The Voyages Issue

docs.abstract: If you believe you were discharged from the military because you are an immigrant, we want to hear from you.
docs.snippet: If you believe you were discharged from the military because you are an immigrant, we want to hear from you.
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the Defense Department has offered immigrants in the United States a fast track to citizenship through military service, but on Thursday, the Associated Press reported that it knew of as least 40 men and women who had been recruited into the Army and then unexpectedly discharged before meeting the required time in service to be naturalized. The report follows recent policy changes under the Trump administration that have led the armed forces to beef up security checks of foreign-born recruits before they reach basic training. If you have been unexpectedly discharged from the military because of your immigration status, we want to hear from you for a coming story.

headline.main: Have You Been Discharged From the Army Because You Are an Immigrant?

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: Sixty-two security force members, one American soldier and 37 civilians were killed during the past week.
docs.snippet: Sixty-two security force members, one American soldier and 37 civilians were killed during the past week.
docs.lead_paragraph: Beginning in September, the Times bureau in Kabul mobilized all of its stringers and Afghan reporters to record every attack on the Afghan security forces that they could find, as a daily chronicle of the war. In this week’s edition, we are adding reports of civilian casualties.
